facts: The New Testament has 27 books that tell about Jesus’ life, the early church, and letters to Christian communities.
The first four books—Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John—are called the Gospels because they share the “good news” about Jesus.
The book of Acts describes how Jesus’ followers spread their message after his resurrection and records events like Pentecost.
Many New Testament letters, called epistles, were written by the apostle Paul to guide churches and answer their questions.
The New Testament was originally written mostly in Greek, which was a common language across the Roman Empire.
Jesus often taught using parables, which are short stories with a moral or spiritual lesson, like the Good Samaritan.
Revelation, the last book of the New Testament, uses vivid symbols and visions to encourage believers to stay hopeful and faithful.
